column11: Review Text

This fort was built in the time of the voc. During the civil war it was the last stronghold of the army. After heavy shelling by the rebels. Badly battered ever since. A visit is worthwhile if you are in Mannar.
Historical place which highlights some era of country. Free to enter. Should have detail/ information boards stabbed.

column8: A new life on its way to Mannar Fort!
column11: Currently in the process of getting restored and conserved Mannar Fort is on its way to show a bit of its past glory.  Built with blocks of coral and brick in the year 1560 by the Portuguese at the entry point of Mannar Island facing the lagoon, had been captured by the Dutch in 1658 and subsequently fallen to British in 1795. Structures within, had stood the test of time with most standing sturdy minus the rooves and the wooden components of doors and windows. It is well fortified with ramparts, moats, and once guarded entrance. Fort is square shaped and the visitor can walk on the rampart almost its full length seeing different views from different directions. From the ramparts there is a beautiful view of the vast span of lagoon that surrounds it. With the low tide boats that are moored in the vicinity gives the appearance that they have collapsed to a side and beached. The church building within the fort is a very interesting site with many ancient burial plaques still remaining in their original spots with beautiful carvings and inscriptions. Stairs leading to a pulpit is visible in the church. Ponds to collect fresh water and wells to supply the needs of the occupants of the Fort are still found with significant levels of water. Fort is one of the must-see places in Mannar.

column8: One of the best place to visit in Mannar.
column11: One of the best place to visit in Mannar. very short distance from city.It is on your right when driving along causeway .This place is being renovated now. You can see a beautiful sunset and a perfect view of lagoon and causeway .Wonder full colonial heritage in Mannar.
Sadly there doesn't seem to be any attempt to restore or maintain these historical places in and around Mannar.  The sunset from the Fort across the bridge is spectacular

column8: Perfect view of lagoon and the road connecting mannar to main island
column11: The ancient Dutch fortress in Mannar. Now it is being restored, some construction work is ongoing. Good place to visit if you are in the area. A perfect view of the lagoon and the bridge can be seen from here.
One of the best place to visit in Mannar.My self and my friend visit this place by walk.This place renovating and probably one of the best in Mannar.

column8: A Fort at a Human Scale
column11: Mannar Fort is different. The influence of Portuguese, Dutch and British architecture is plain to see. What makes it even more attractive is its size and scale. Because it is not a sprawling building and has many features of interest, the fort experience is digestible and at a human scale. Much still needs to be done to renovate this old lady but it has a charm and interest all of its own. Well worth the visit!
If you haven't visited any other fort in Sri lanka or elsewhere its worth going. For someone from the past it says a lot of sad past. Prison and so on

column8: Old fortress need some real attention
column11: It was in the morning, we visit the fortress as advised by our guide. And thank God we followed his advice, it was so hot and humid once the sun came up. you can see the whole lagoon from this place and it's must visit place in Mannar.
A good place to see itâ€™s a very good nature made surrounding with Dutch culture made building with the sea facings

Slap bang in the middle of town. Under renovation right now. No signs to indicate significance of structures / rooms. A few plaques in memory of people who departed long ago is the only indicator of the age of the place (going back to 1850s I think). A lot more need sto be done to make this interesting to visitors.

Strange location to protect Mannar from the sea,clearly the enemy is from the mainland.  Broken down and needing repair, bears a history of the Portuguese and the recent times of the war when it changed hands and shows the effort in holding on to it.
Good s this is a fort only and hasn't been bombarded by tourist shops etc.  Some information boards would be good, but it is free to enter and walk around
This is an old Fort you will see on your right just before you enter the Manner town.A must for anyone visiting here.
This is landmark of Mannar. Situated near the lagoon just starting the town. Spread over a big area. very old buildings ruined. Must see place as  its not far from the town.
visited there around 12.30 pm. super hot. it was near the lagoon. off road. easy to find it. it was made by sand & salt bricks.
a pity more care is not taken of this wonderful place.  made with such precision and have stood the test of time.  the view from the top of the fort is super.
Very interesting and historical place, needs maintenance and cleaning up. Good place for some nice photos.
Much bigger than I'd expected.  Get up on the battlements and walk all the way round.  Also see from land side and from the causeway.
Its an old dutch fort built in the 1500's in bad shape now if you are in mannar this a place you can visit

This was by far the best day we spent exploring the old Portuguese / Dutch forts in Sri Lanka. The fort was built by the Portuguese in 1560, converted by the Dutch in 1696, and handed over to the British in 1795. Away from the crowds of the Galle Fort, the continuing military presence of the Kalpitiya and Trincomallee's Fort Fredrick, and the workmen restoring the Jaffna fort you can spend as much time as you need exploring the old fort, with just the wild donkeys for company! Look for the old church, barracks and tombstones that are quite well preserved for a place that is essentially abandoned. There is no information present at the site. We enjoyed the tranquil solitude of the place, took lots of photos and researched at our leisure.
Other fortresses in sri lanka are nicely not abandoned and nicely maintained. but this is abandoned and even looks like haunted ðŸ˜‚ its good for photographers by the way

Another Dutch fort that has been neglected. However the internal structures are still intact minus the roofs. Gives you a good idea as to how the forts internal structure and set up was. There are few graves with inscriptions as well. This fort I believe will be the highlight of all the forts if proper restoration is done.
Unless a historian whose interest is in examining ruins,  this fort does not warrant a scheduled stop.  However this is one of the few 'tourist attractions' in Mannar
A quaint ruin of a three centuries old Dutch fort that has been used for various purposes until recently

Its a historical place in Mannar and, a must go location for the history lovers. Walking among the remains of the old fort gives one a taste of history. A pleasant evening walk with good views. I don't know why the authorities failed to display some information on the historical value of the location.

This old Portugese and Dutch fort is not designed for visitors. It is basically a ruined fort which may have had some maintenance. You just wander around searching for things that interest you. There is no information about it at the sight. Still we found it inteesting and pleasant just before sunset.

This fort is in a lovely setting and is great to wander around in the evening to catch the sunset. There's not much to see as so much of it has crumbled away. Walking along the outer walls is lovely and romantic with great views. Nice palmyras trees growing in the middle of the fort. There's no information, so just let your imagination go wild or read up yourself separately.
Enjoyed visiting the Mannar Fort and walking around it. Would recommend it to anyone visiting Mannar.
We went there around sunset and it was nice but just like most of the Dutch forts around SL this too is rather neglected. No guides so you will need to read up about it before or later on.
This is one of the historical fort located in Mannar and very popular among tourists. This is one of the must see place in Mannar
Ã€n interesting relic, but in a pretty delapidated state. Given some investment and a general tidy-up it has the potential to attract much needed tourists  to this area.
This has been constructed by Dutch while they were ruling SL. The place has a historic value. You can have a better look of the around from the top of this place.

This colonial military fort was first built by the Portuguese around 1560 AD and then used by the Dutch and the British. It fell under the control of the Tamil Tigers during the country's civil war and has been been abandoned and neglected for many years. It is sad and depressing to see the ancient walls, ramparts and what is left of the buildings being taken over by vegetation. An old church inside has the remains of an alter, baptismal pond and many old Dutch gravestones. This heritage structure should really be converted into a museum and tourist information office for Mannar Island.

The fort in Mannar has been damaged in the civil war. Still the walls and some of the ancient buildings are not so bad damaged. You can walk over the ramp, see the interior of the church and other buildings. It would be a great place if it was renovated. Still it's quite interesting.
Bulid by tbe Dutch during 17th century. Poorly maintained. Beautiful view of the ocean and Mannar town.
You can enter in by your vehicle freely and freely observe the things inside. No rush. Very calm and quit.

Mannar Fort - An Abundant Treasure in Mannar This 15th Century Mannar Fort welcomes you at the entry point of the Mannar Island. As like the other forts around Sri Lanka, this fort also was under the rule of Portuguese, Dutch and finally British â€¦â€¦ Like the other forts in the north, the long lasted conflict made a huge distruction to this fort as wellâ€¦. The structure is severely damaged and the very sad thing is it is used as a dumping at a point inside the fort. Still, it is a not missed attraction during the visit to mannar.

Although the fort isn't in its original form, it was very interesting to walk around. You can walk along the top of the walls and through the rooms. When we visited the fort a small boxing ring has been set up for the local team to practice before they entered a competition in Jaffna the next day. We spent time resting in the shade under the tree in the courtyard and several Sri Lankan families visited whilst we were there. It is a free attraction and very easy to find from the bus station. If you want to see a fort in its original form you can visit the Dutch fort in Jaffna or Galle.
This place dosen't look what its actually supposed to look like anymore sadly its in ruins and has taken so many of the bullets to its walls during the internal conflict.

Nice ancient ruin building. It a nice Dutch fort. I love the architecture and how things built in a very small space. Love the remains of the church. Must see location of u come here. Wish government can re build it and make it more attractive tourist destination
Still we can see the ruins of old fort. Many important areas such as the places used to hang the victims are destroying due poor conservation.

The road to Mannar is long and straight passing through some exceptional landscapes - in fact very similar to the approach to Jaffna. Following the war, roads and rail lines have been restored to a very high standard Unfortunately not so much attention has been paid to the fabric of historic buildings. That being said it is possible to walk the ramparts of the Dutch fort and see the foot print of the buildings that once occupied the site. As visitor numbers to this neglected part of the country increase I am sure that the value of relics such as this will become more appreciated and are likely to undergo restoration the likes of which can be seen in Galle

large fort, very dammaged, especially by theTamil war. In ancient history it served its purposes very well and you can see that from the remains. You can easily climb on top of it and you can walk almost the entire way around. Views are very nice, but because of all the dammaged parts it is more a ruine than an existing fort.

A wonderful experience. The fort itself is badly lacking maintenance and restoration. Used as a barrack during the conflict it now needs to be reclaimed by the Department of Archaeology and restored to its former glory. Can be a great attraction for the region esp during the off season for migratory birds for more tourists.

It is isolated small fort as you enter the island. The road way is not even cleared to such gem been neglected. The fort must have been restored and open to public like most other forts around the country

The archeological authorities should take action to preserve this important Fort. Portuguese and Dutch evidence could be found here. People are climbing the walls which are about 500 years old. No one to prevent these.

The fort in manner has rich history embedded in it. Walk around and explore the fort. Some chambers keeps you guessing as to what they were used as in the past when the Dutch used to rule the country. Just as you enter the premises and turn left, you get a slope going up which puts you near a tall structure(either a bell tower/gallows), just as you go up, there's a small passageway just adjoining it on the left, its supposed to be the dungeon.
shame , we should restore this heritage for our younger generation to really see.There is so much history attached to these places.
Bordered by Mannar lagoon from one side, this gives a photogenic look together with the adjacent bridge.

It's a small fort and it's not as large and well kept as the Galle fort. there is a lot of Dutch influence and a couple of dutch gravestones,  nothing much to see inside other than that. But it's a good stop if you're in the area.

Similar to Jaffna fort but less affected by the war. The scenery around is worthwhile. Has the Palm Trees (Thal) thats more significant in the nothern part of Sri Lanka and donkeys freely roaming in the on the massive walls. A truly unmodified experience.

My second favorite Fort in Sri Lanka (2nd to Galle of course). Almost completely intact apart from the roofs, this is ruin wandering at its best. A walk around the rampart offers superb 380 degree views of the Mannar township and the expansive waterways that were once graced with tall ships. Palm trees fringe the courtyard and old Dutch tombstones add to the mystique. There is a cellar which stunk of Bat poo and was a little spooky, so didn't spend too much time in there! Quite a crowd of locals gathered at sunset to enjoy the view. Definitely worth visiting and easy to drive to being situated to the right of the bridge into Mannar town.

The road leading to the entrance of the Fort is just off to the side of the main bridge that connects the island to mainland. A small bus can drive through the broken entrance to the court yard. The fort was built by the Portuguese in 1560 and it surrendered to the Dutch on 22 February 1658 and was rebuilt by the Dutch in 1696. On 5 October 1795 the Dutch surrendered to the British. The fort has four bastions and itâ€™s still in good condition. The inside has fallen into ruins. There a large number of buildings scattered throughout the fort. A chapel alter and a number of plaques indicate that number of people have been buried inside the church. During the civil war the fort was occupied by the forces. Now it is under the Archaeological department and it has been cleaned to enable to visitors to walk around the fort. The fortress is mentioned in the Portuguese 17th century iconographic sources as a quadrangular construction with three bastions and with shape and position apparently identical to those of the present-day fortress. The fort has been amilitary fort from the  1560â€™s. Definitely worth a visit.
